01/11: Pipelay was completed 10/99 by Allseas Construction Contractors, with JP Kenny contracted for engineering. A 27 km, 102 mm diameter monoethylene glycol (MEG) pipeline as well as two 508 mm diameter flowlines connect five subsea wells in the Pluto and Xena gas fields, located approximately 190 km northwest of Karratha, to an offshore processing platform. Gas is transported from the platform via a 180 km, 914 mm diameter trunkline, piggybacked by a 152 mm diameter MEG line, to a single 4.3 MMt/a LNG production train at the Burrup LNG Park.

09/08: Galsi and Snam Rete Gas have signed an agreement committing to the construction of the Italian section of a new pipeline importing gas from Algeria to Italy via Sardinia.  The agreement comes in the wake of a memorandum of understanding signed in November 2007, and will see Galsi develop the engineering and obtain the main permits and authorisations required, while Snam Rete Gas will build the pipeline and managed the gas transport activities. The pipeline will be around 900km long, of which 600km will be offshore at a maximum depth of around 2,800 msw. The offshore sections will run from the Algerian coast to southern Sardinia, where it will link with the Italian section, and from Olbia, northern Sardinia, to Tuscany. Its initial transportation capacity when brought onstream in 2012 will be 283 billion scf/year.

07/08: Melrose Resources and Bulgargaz have concluded that the Galata field in the Black Sea is ideally suited for conversion to a gas storage scheme, and intend to carry out the first phase of work during 2009.  Joint feasibility studies have confirmed that the high quality reservoir properties, existing infrastructure and location mean that Galata is suited for use as a gas storage reservoir. The first phase of development will require an investment of around USD 30 million to reconfigure the existing field compression, tie-back the suspended Galata East No.2 well and install additional metering facilities. This first phase would provide usable storage capacity of around 25 billion scf of gas. Phases two and three would each require similar levels of investment to the first phase and would increase the capacity to 42 billion scf and 60 billion scf of gas respectively.

11/12: Ocean Vanguard completes 16/2-14 delineation well. It encountered a 30m oil column in upper jurassic reservoir rocks of very good quality. The oil/water contact was not encountered and it was drilled to a vertical depth of 1,960 metres in a water depth of 113 msw. The well will be permanently plugged and abandoned.

09/12: Statoil has spudded the appraisal well 16/2-14. The well will appraisde the crestal part of Johan Sverdrup. The main objective is to determine the thickness and quality of jurassic age sandstone reservoir on a structural high between the previous appraisal wells 16/2-8 and 16/2-10.

9/12: the full field development may cost NOK 100 billion (USD 17.5 billion), according to Statoil.  The FPSO and the concrete base options ruled out, jacket type platform preferred. Concept selection Q4 2013, PDO submission Q4 2014. Startup in 2018. 

7/12: Lundin has commenced the drilling of appraisal well 16/2-13 on the north eastern part  of the Johan Sverdrup discovery. The well is 2.5km north east of discovery well 16/2-6, made in 2010. The main objective is to determine the top reservoir, its quality and thickness and oil/water contact in this part of the field. The well will be drilled to 2150 metres and is expected to take 45 days.

Field is 35km south of the Grane oil export pipeline, which has significant spare capacity.

07/08: StatoilHydro has submitted a new PDO for the Troll field.  The scheme includes a new gas injection plant for improved oil recovery on the Troll B platform, a 35-in gas pipeline from the Troll A platform to the Kollsnes gas plant and replacement production pipes in the gas wells running up to Troll A in the Troll East Area. There will also be modifications on Troll A and the Kollsnes terminal. According to the operator, gas injection in Troll West will increase the oil reserves at Troll by 17 million barrels. Offshore modification are scheduled to start later this year with the gas injection plant in place by late 2010 or early 2011. The 35-in gas pipeline is expected on stream in 2011.

07/08: StatoilHydro has submitted a new PDO for the Troll field.  The scheme includes a new gas injection plant for improved oil recovery on the Troll B platform, a 35-in gas pipeline from the Troll A platform to the Kollsnes gas plant and replacement production pipes in the gas wells running up to Troll A in the Troll East Area. There will also be modifications on Troll A and the Kollsnes terminal. According to the operator, gas injection in Troll West will increase the oil reserves at Troll by 17 million barrels. Offshore modification are scheduled to start later this year with the gas injection plant in place by late 2010 or early 2011. The 35-in gas pipeline is expected on stream in 2011.

The Volund field consists of 3 production and 1 water injection wells. The production wells will be tied back via four-slot manifold and production and gas lift pipeline systems to the Alvheim facilities. A flexible water injection flowline will be routed from the Choke and Metering Skid (CMS), adjacent to the Alvheim East Riser Base, to the water injection well at Volund. All control functions for the Volund field will be provided by a static control umbilical, which will be routed between the CMS and the Volund manifold.

11/12: A "subsea step-out" from Global Producer-3. The work will include short flexible jumpers rather than flowlines. Offshore work to take place in 2013.
5/14: DOF to use Normand Reach to replace the Dumbarton Drill Cluster Centre (DCC) flexible production riser  at the Global Producer 3 FPSO .

6/01: Total is hoping to develop Dunbar South by the end of the year. Most likely development will be 17km subsea tie-back to Dunbar platform.

2/97: Total could reactivate Dunbar South development later this year. 

1/97: Total "suspending" plans for development of Dunbar S following very poor results from recent appraisal well.

10/96: Rockwater is bidding for installation of 6-in rigid steel line for potential development of Dunbar South development next season.
Converted drilling semi 'Deep Sea Saga'. Unit moved to Vietnam in 1993 for BHP Petroleum.

10/12: Fairfield says GBP 70 million (USD 113.4 million) has been spent on Dunlin upgrades. A new fuel gas import system and modified water injection system should allow production to rise to a year-end exit rate of around 10,000 boe/d. For the first time since early 2000, the operator will be able to use its own independent power generation system to achieve higher and sustained water injection performance.

6/13: Fairfield to apply for derogation to leave the substructure in place. Only topsides likely to be removed.  Drilling deck weighs 4,735 tonnes, module deck weighs 9140 tonnes and lower deck weighs 5,931 tonnes. Reserve installation, piece small and single lift all methods under consideration.
Dunlin A CoP will be 2018 at the earliest.

02/08: Bridge Resources has begun drilling the production well on its Durango field in Block 48/21a.  Drilling, completion and testing of well 48/21a-4 will take around two months. Bridge Resources, which has a 100 per cent working interest in Durango, previously named Dudgeon, believes the discovery could contain reserves of up to 42.4 billion scf of gas. The well will be tied back 14.3km to the Perenco-operated Waveney platform in Block 48/17c. From there, gas is transported by pipeline to the onshore Bacton processing plant. Durango was first discovered by Placid Oil in 1967, but has remained undeveloped since then.

Gas and condensate development tied back to Waveney Platform Block 48/17c.
Initial 4yr contract. Due to disappointing fld results, FPSO was removed in mid-1999 and contract expired w/o vessel returning to service.

01/14: Three wells on Babbage, Hunter and Johnston fields to be abandoned. Campaign to start on Feb 4. 
11/13: Well Ops has won this, Well Enhancer to be used. Abandonment of three firm wells, further two wells optional. 
Abandonment of suspended exploration wells in the UK sector, E.ON is tendering at the moment.

09/12:  Faroe Petroleum acquired 10 per cent non-operated interest in East Foinaven Field from Marubeni Oil & Gas (North Sea) Limited as part of USD 32 million cash deal. Remaining proved plus probable reserves, as of 1 January 2012, was estimated at 1.55 million boe, with gross production from the field this year expected to average about 3500 boe/d.

2010: 4 wells (2p + 2wi) drilled between 2001-2005

02/14: Production started at East Rochelle. West Rochelle to start up again shortly after. 
01/14: First production at East Rochelle has been delayed due to severe weather conditions. Revised startup date currently unknown. 
10/13: First gas announced. Initial production is from West Rochelle. Drilling continues on East Rochelle, which is expected to be online during Q4 2013. All prodcution will be processed at Scott platform. 
7/13: First production date has been pushed back to September 2013 due to maintenance work on the Scott host platform.
5/13: At the completion stage for first well on West Rochelle.
02/13: Drillings ops on the East Rochelle well have been supsended after the cement on the well was damaged in a storm. The rig will now move to drill the West Rochelle well, which will take 120 days, so first production will be significantly delayed. 
10/12: First production now expected in Jan 2013. 
07/12: First of two development wells set to commence drilling shortly. There has been some delay to the installation programme following the slippage in the arrival of the Technip pipelay vessel. Partner Premier says upgrade to the Scott platform remains on track.


04/12: Development drilling imminent as of April 24. To be developed by two horizontal gas producers, one on East Rochelle and one on West Rochelle. The wells will target the Lower Cretaceous Britannia Sandstone Reservoir. A pilot hole will be drilled on each to aid positioning of the horizontal wellbore within the reservoir.  The East Rochelle well will be drilled by the Ocean Nomad. West Rochelle well will be drilled by the WilHunter rig.

01/12: FDP approved. 
11/11: PDO revised to include West Rochelle, DECC expected to approve it by end of 2011.
7/11: Pre unit agreement for East and West Rochelle means operator Endeavour holds 44%, Nexen holds  41% and Premier holds 15%.

4/11: FDP approved. Commercial terms for processing of production on Scott platform agreed. Contracts to be awarded immediately. 1-well 30-km tie-back to Scott. Start up - Q4 2012.

1/11: ss & topsides FEED completed and procurement phase began in Q4 2010.

07/14: Development launched. The development plan comprises the conversion of the discovery well into a production well and a 16km production pipeline tied back to the main Laggan-Tormore flowline. Edradour is estimated to cost GBP 340 million to develop and has en expected start date of the fourth quarter of 2017. 
01/13: FID expected in Q1 2014. 
11/12: Total expects first production in 2015. The project will consist of a subsea tie-back to the under-construction Laggan-Tormore infrastructure, around 17km away. A four-slot manifold will be used for the development and the development well will be a completion of a previously-drilled exploration well on the field. Total is carrying out FEED work at the moment and tendering for infrastructure will follow. An environmental statement was submitted to the DECC in October 2012.

10/12: Environmental statement submitted.

3/11: Total wants to develop the field at the same time as Laggan/Tormore. Edradour sits 50km from future exportline from Laggan/Tormore to Sullom Voe. Appraisal to be drilled in summer 2011.

03/12: Platform evacuated and 3km shipping exclusion zone put around it after gas leak. Shell has also moved 120 non-essential staff from the Shearwater platform and Hans Deul drilling rig as a precaution. Stand-by vessel observed "sea boiling".
10/14: Start up scheduled for end of 2014.

Converted drilling semi 'Ali Baba'.  Unit sold to Seatankers Management Company 11/95.  The 8-Nov-2004 ATP confirms that it has changed the name of its Emerald field to "Cheviot".  Vessel to be marketed for worldwide use by Oceaneering Intl.  The 8-Nov-2004 ATP confirms that it has changed the name of its Emerald field to "Cheviot".

02/14: Production to resume in early 2014. 
3/13:  Production is not expected to restart unitl late 2013 or early 2014.
8/12:This well was taken offline earlier to complete some required maintenance work on the wellhead system, and it's likely this well will be out for the rest of this year.

10/14: FDP approved by DECC in Sept 2013. Start up now expected end of 2014. 
7/11: ES issued. 1-well 8km tie-back to Callanish. Start-up in Q3 2013. 1 more well may be added at a later stage, depending on the outcome of the first well.

Venture will seek approval to develop Ensign once it has agreed commercial terms for the export of the gas with ConocoPhillips.

Field renamed as Eris from Channon. Barbarossa renamed Ceres.

 Likely joint development with Barbarossa. SS tie-back to Mercury SS manifold.

2011: Encore taken over by Premier.

05/14:  BP is planning a major renewal programme 
for the field in the coming years. An accommodation ‘flotel’, to 
provide more bed space, will be deployed to allow long-term 
reliability, fabrication and new well work to be performed alongside 
near-term, production-adding work. BP sees significant potential 
and remaining field life in the ETAP asset – a reason why, in 2012, 
the company increased its equity share in the asset.
05/09 Start up delayed to mid-summer 2009. FPSO to produce three wells. Nexen approved plan in early '06. USD 575 MM total development cost. Bluewater won job with Aoka Mizu baredeck hull.

11/13: Atlantic advises that the Ettrick well is due to come onstream in November. 
09/13: Expected to come on-stream imminently after the annual Aoka Mizu FPSO shut-down in 3Q 2013 


5/13:  One infill production well to be drilled near the crest of the field. To be brought onstream towards the end of Q3 2013.

2/13: BG says startup expected in Q1 2013.
04/12: First production now expected in late 2012.
02/10: BG applied to DECC for consent to develop Everest Ph IV. 4 new wells will be drilled and tied to N Everest facilities.
One well tie-back to Kestrel.

03/14: Well did find quantity of hydrocarbons but not enough to make it economically viable so has now been plugged and abandoned. 
5/13: Taqa to drill exploration well 210/25a-11 this summer with semi John Shaw. If successful as expected, it will be completed as a producer and brought onstream by November.

If Fulla finds oil, the two fields will be developed together using a leased FPSO. œ300MM is assumed development cost for a FPSO + 6 ss wells development. Sanction is planned for 2012 & 1st oil in 2014. If Fulla is unsuccessful, Freya will be tied back 10km to Clair.

FDP must be submitted by August 31, 2014 and must have reasonable assurance that first poduction will be achieved prior to November 25, 2016. Upon approval of FDP, Enegi-ABTechnology will earn right to acquire 50 per cent working interest in licence, Antrim will remain operator.

02/12: East Fyne well plugged and abandoned after column of oil bearing sands was found to be thinner than expected. Decision on viability of this project is now expected at end of Q2 2012.

01/12: FPSO still the favourite. Project sanction still expected in early 2012. Teekay Petrojarl could supply FPSO.
08/11: FPSO development understood to be preferred. Development expected to be sanctioned in early 2012.

05/11: All three development options - tie back; FPSO or NUI - are still being considered, with a concept selection now expected in Q4 2011. This is to allow appraisal drilling in East Fyne to be completed. Partner Antrim expects the field to start up in mid-2013, but this aggressive timeline seems unlikely.

12/10: Teekay Petrojarl I has been considered for this field, if it does not go to Bream.

11/10: FPSO, ss tie-back & NUI options are being looked at. Concept selection Q1 2011, FDP submission Q2 2012 & start-up in 2014, according to Premier. Tie-back options: Triton FPSO (22km), Shell's Guillemot or Wintershall's Blakeney.
Talisman expected to takeover charter when it expires in Jan 2005, for work on the Galley field. Talisman decision expected in April 2004.

04/08: Likely to be single well tie-back to Schooner.

4/13: First Oil still seeking partners to fund appraisal well drilling. The operator believes that an appraisal well could potentially increase the STOIIP to over 90 mmbbls and double the recoverable volume associated with Glenn. 
17 MM BOE est. for oil in place. First Oil took over operatorship in 2009, but little movement on project since. Development would likely be via ss tieback to existing Tweedsmuir or Buzzard facilities.

10/14: Expected on stream in 2015.

10/12: first oil still expected in late 2014.

7/12: Project on course for first production in late 2014, says Nexen. Platform fabrication well underway and construction on time and on budget.

5/12: Teamtrade has been awarded a frame agreement by Cameron for instrumentation of Xmas trees. Running for eight years with two five-year options, this contract will initially cover deliveries to ConocoPhillips’ GEAD project.

10/11: DECC decides not to pursue Longannet CCS project, but Peterhead CCS project still ongoing, and still bidding for DECC/NER 300 funding. Peterhead CCS would use Goldeneye for CO2 storage. Would use existing trunkline.

6/12: Shell is seeking a slot on a jackup for a four-month programme on Goldeneye. The rig would cover either abandonment duties OR work associated with the redevelopment of the field into a CCS project. Rig is being sought between 2014 and 2017, so date is an estimate.

12/07: Wintershall has identified a possible export route for development of its Monterey gas field that it believes would "reduce non-well capital expenditure significantly".  Licence partner Black Rock Oil and gas advised that "cautious progress" has been made towards development during the past six months, and that through evaluation of results from the 49/8c-4 well and modelling of horizontal well technology, the partners were positive on plans for development. Both Wintershall and Black Rock declined to identify the proposed export route, although a source within Wintershall confirmed that "there is a potential development concept on its way" for which internal and external approval is pending and still to be finalised.

An appraisal well will be drilled on the field this year. First production from Monterey is targeted for late 2007, early 2008. Field has estimated mean recoverable gas reserves of 165 billion cubic feet.

OGX reprocessed geological data and concluded that the intense compartmentalization and discontinuity of its reservoirs will compromise their productivity.

The project is part of the Area A Gas Management (AAGM) program designed to eliminate routine flaring in Block 0 and in the Malongo Terminal area onshore. The program includes three projects: flare and relief modifications (FARM) to existing facilities in the
Takula and Malongo fields; the new four-pile Takula Gas Processing Platform (TGPP) to compress the collected gas from the Takula field for processing,local gas lift and export to the Malongo field for injection; and the Cabinda Gas Plant (CGP), which will receive natural gas liquids (NGLs) extracted at the TGPP facility and the liquids collected from gas recovered at the Malongo Terminal.

4/12: EGP3B has been divided into Stage 1 and Stage 2. Stage 1 involved modifications to six existing platforms, an upgrade of the Meren compression platform and a new 32km pipeline. 

the aim is to eliminate routine flaring of natural gas that is associated with the production of crude oil. The project includes installation of a 120 million scf/d natural-gas-gathering and compression platform near the existing Meren 1 complex, installation of approximately 75 miles (121 km) of subsea pipelines, and modifications to nine existing production platforms.
4/12: Stage 2 will involve the construction of the new Meren GGCP platform as well as gas gathering pipelines and production platform modifications.

ORIGINAL SCOPE
4 new flow stations with gas gathering
Central processing facility (CPF)
25 wells
6 new platforms in estuary
ADDITIONAL SCOPE
Switch from LNG to domestic gas market
1 non-associated gas wells
Renew estuary platforms & subsea bulk lines
PRODUCTION
90 kbbl/d to Forcados terminal
60 mmscf/d to domestic gas

2013: Chevron and Shell have officially pulled out of the Olokola LNG plant. NNPC will struggle to fund the proposed 6.3 million tonnes per year project on its own.

The Sonam field is expected to come onstream in 2016, with gas to be sent to the Escravos Gas Plant.

12/07: Contractors have revealed they expect further delays of up to a year on the Olokola LNG project.  The scheme has encountered problems since pre-qualification documents for an EPIC tender were issued in February of this year. The workscope covered 15 pipelines of up to 30-in diameter. Tendering also began at the same time for three 48-in pipelines. Complex negotiations over the Nigerian government's regulation of the sector is understood to be behind the current delays which are predicted to last several months. An EPIC tender covering four wellhead platforms expected in October could still be some way off.

10/07: Progress further delayed due to Nigerian government's plan for scheme. ITT for EPIC wellhead platform contract had been expected 10/07. Pre-qual docs issued Feb for pipelines

02/08: Start up of the West African Gas Pipeline project has been delayed until April.  It is understood the main pipeline had been completed by the end of December but the Nigeria Gas Company needs to carry out repairs to its own feeder pipelines ahead of bringing the scheme on stream. The pipeline will transport gas from Nigeria to Benin, Togo and Ghana. Horizon Offshore was contracted for the main pipeline work which was delayed due to rocks on the seabed and damage to the pipeline caused by an anchor. The USD 620 million West African Gas Pipeline starts at the Itoki terminal in southeastern Nigeria and heads eastward through Benin and Togo waters to reach Takoradi in western Ghana.
